Lynn's early flurry earns D-2 men's soccer title

Tom Whitus, Special to The Courier-Journal 9:30 p.m. EST December 6, 2014

Lynn University's Chris Hellmann (23) battles for the ball against the Charleston's Jordan Lavender (5). Hellmann scored two goals as Lynn won 3-2.(Photo: David Lee Hartlage/Special to The C-J)

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Sophomore forward Chris Hellmann scored two goals in the first half as Lynn University took control early, then held on to post a 3-2 win over the University of Charleston (W. Va.) in the NCAA Division II men's soccer championship yesterday at Bellarmine University's Frazier Stadium.

Charleston (22-1-1) came into the game unbeaten with an 83-9 goal differential, but it took the Lynn Fighting Knights (19-1-1) just over 30 minutes in the first half to notch three goals.

"We made some mistakes in the first half, which was very uncharacteristic," said Charleston coach Chris Grassie. "We were just off."

But two goals by the Golden Eagles in the final 12 minutes made it close. They had a chance to tie it in the final seconds – but the Lynn defense made the slim lead stand, giving the Fighting Knights their second title in three years.

Story continues after the gallery.

    The first goal was a stunner. Lynn freshman forward Nicolas Mortensen, from Copenhagen, Denmark, took advantage of some sloppy defense to get control of the ball in front of the goal.

    From there, Mortensen's 25-yard rocket of a shot slipped through the hands of goalkeeper Fabian Veit and into the net, giving Lynn a 1-0 lead at the 3:24 mark.

    Just over three minutes later, Hellmann used a free kick from 25 yards out to curl a shot from the right side past Veit's outstretched arms and into the net. With 6:45 elapsed, Lynn had a 2-0 lead.

    "I played against that keeper in Germany," Hellmann said of Veit. "I knew I could beat him on that side."

    Hellmann, from Cologne, Germany, wasn't finished. With time running out in the half, he stole a pass in front of the Golden Eagles goal and slid a shot into the corner of the goal past Veit. That made it 3-0 with 31:35 gone in the half.

    "Everything we said we wanted to do (in the first half), we did," said Lynn coach John Rootes.

    Lynn's defense, meanwhile, was keeping the potent Charleston offense out of the net. Goalkeeper Lucas Fancello had two dynamite saves in the first half, helping Lynn to the locker room with a 3-0 lead.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Grand Valley keeps D2 women's soccer title

    It was much the same for most of the second half. But because Lynn couldn't convert any scoring chances, it almost let the lead slip away in the final minutes.

    Fancello, a freshman from Martigues, France, was caught flat as Lewis Osborne passed to Jules Gabbiadini, who scored to make it 3-1 with 11:05 remaining.

    "I think we got a little panicky," said Rootes. "We gave them chances."

    The momentum shifted from there, but the Fighting Knights were able to hold the two-goal lead until the final moments. With 41 seconds left, a foul in the penalty box gave the Golden Eagles a penalty kick. Will Roberts responded with a shot past Fancello and it was 3-2.

    Charleston would have one more chance to score – a free kick from midfield with eight seconds left, but couldn't convert – ending its 26-game win streak.

    CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE
